awd_titl_txt: MRI: Acquisition of an 18GHz to 110GHz Millimeter-Wave Anechoic Chamber
awd_abstract_narration:
Fifth generation (5G) cellular and millimeter-wave (mm-wave) networks are expected to play a significant role in next generation communication and sensing systems. Indeed, mm-wave technology provides multi-Gigabit-per-second (Gbps) data rates to mobile and Internet-of-Things (IoT) devices, projected to grow to 200 billion by 2020. Currently, 5G/mm-wave research is very active. However, to effectively study, design, and characterize 5G/mm-wave systems, new state-of-the-art instrumentation is needed, traditionally not present in academic labs. The proposed instrumentation will provide unprecedented measurement and characterization capabilities of 5G/mm-wave antennas and devices. Therefore, it will enable Florida International University (FIU) to: (a) conduct current and future cutting-edge 5G/ mm-wave research projects, (b) develop novel 5G/mm-wave technologies for cellular networks, satellite and airborne communications,  as well as brain studies and cancer diagnoses and treatments, (c) offer new opportunities to train post-docs, graduate, undergraduate, and K-12 students to become experts in high frequency radio frequency (RF) technologies, creating much needed national workforce in this area, (d) serve as a state-of-the-art technical hub in South Florida, attracting new statewide, national and international academic and industry collaborators, (e) foster new opportunities for cross-disciplinary and multi-institutional research, and (f) support the growth of a strong and diverse U.S. workforce in RF communication. Therefore, the proposed instrumentation will have significant impact in research, education, and technology development. This acquisition will further advance FIU's educational efforts to broaden participation of women and other underrepresented groups in STEM through curriculum development, REU programs, and outreach efforts. 

The proposed instrumentation from Microwave Vision Group (MVG), called -Lab, is highly specialized and incorporates important requirements for compatibility and interoperability, across 18 GHz to 110 GHz. This instrumentation consists of an anechoic chamber equipped with absorbers, precision positioning control system, RF equipment modules (network analyzers, coaxial cables, waveguides, probes, etc.) and data post-processing.  Different modules are required for different frequency bands viz. K (18-26 GHz), Ka (26-40 GHz), V (50-75GHz), and W (75-110GHz) bands. Research in the frequency range 18-110 GHz has so far been impeded by the lack of affordable testing equipment with large measurement inaccuracies. This is mostly due to the small footprint of related RF devices. As a result, research activities in related communications, biomedical, and other scientific fields have been so far limited to much lower frequency range. The procurement of such instrumentation will eschew traditional limitations often encountered with high frequency testing and characterization of future mm-wave, terahertz, and IoT components devices and systems. The broadband frequency (18-110GHz) offered by this instrumentation will enable groundbreaking and transformative research in RF communications with multi-Gbps data rates.  Such capability will revolutionize a) cellular networks, b) airborne and satellite communication systems, c) vehicle-to-vehicle communications, d) reconfigurable and deployable RF systems, e) wearable and implantable devices, f) brain and cancer studies, g) terahertz and mm-wave cameras, h) terahertz sources and on-chip terahertz antennas, and i) secure communications among others.  In summary, research in 5G and mm-wave technologies, which will be enabled by the proposed instrumentation, is expected to have great impact on information technology, telecommunications, diagnosis of diseases and biomonitoring, thereby improving quality of life and health.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_div_long_name: Division of Electrical, Communications and Cyber Systems

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: REU SUPP-Res Exp for Ugrd Supp

por.por_cntn:
Through this MRI grant, Florida International University (FIU) has acquired a 5G anechoic chamber that operates across a large frequency band, ranging from 18GHz to 110GHz. This band is crucial for upcoming 5G communication systems, among several other applications. Currently, research in this frequency range is impeded by the lack of accurate testing equipment. Those available suffer from measurement inaccuracies due to the small footprint of RF devices at such high frequencies and associated high losses. As a result, technology-potential of this frequency band in communications, biomedical, and other scientific areas is untapped. 

The  MVG/Orbit FR μ-Lab from is a compact and portable system specifically designed for the collection of far-field and spherical near-field electromagnetic data off millimeter die chips and miniature antenna assemblies. The manufacturer was chosen after careful review of its products design and cost benefits. This chamber is state-of-the-art machinery in terms of its size, processing capability, safety features and ease of maintenance. It is the most flexible and versatile system for performing antenna characterization and measurement across very large bandwidths.

The chamber was delivered and installed in the RFCOM lab in February 2021. The vendor provided a week of training for super users. Since then, the chamber has been fully operational and helped characterize antennas from 18 to 110GHz. Since then, the chamber has been used by graduate and undergraduate students working on designing millimeter-wave antennas.  Many journal and conference papers were published on antennas that were characterized by the chamber. 

Overall, this anechoic chamber is providing an indispensable in-house tool for testing and characterizing next-generation millimeter-wave sensors, IoT components, and communication systems. This will allow the introduction of new paradigms in RF communications, particularly for future 5G, satellite communications, and medical applications. The broadband frequency ranging from 18GHz to 110 GHz offers unprecedented capability, previously unavailable, to characterize antennas and design new systems all the way from low frequency bands to mm-wave. Notably, the chamber has ubiquitous use across many research groups at FIU and other institutions in the region.

In addition, this acquisition has augmented the research infrastructure at FIU and offered rare opportunity to train post-docs, graduate, and undergraduate students to become experts in high frequency RF technologies, creating much needed national workforce in this area.



Last Modified: 01/04/2023
Modified by: Elias A Alwan
